comment: Professor Mapes, does not grade when she's supposed too! Weeks behind on grading and giving feedback which we're supposed to receive before doing our speeches! She's also not accessible outside of class. I gave up on emailing her because it would take days or a week for her to respond! Do not recommend!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Mapes was quite understanding the times I had to contact her, though she was very unavailable all things considered. She was very behind on grading and often didn't grade our written work before the speeches were already submitted. Lots of easy busy work that often took a lot of time to get done. Very fair grader and gives good feedback!

This professor is very slow at grading. Initially, she did a great job, but after speech two, we did not hear from her for three weeks. It is difficult because she is supposed to give feedback on our written work before we give the speech. I also have most of the work in this class out of all four of my online classes.

She was great. Class compiled of 4 major speeches Written Work, the speech video and a refection are do for all 4. Uses Achieve for assignments and quizzes which is super simple. 2 exams that are not video monitored but you should know all the information on them if you do the assignments. Tech savvy and a really quick responder. 100% Recommend her

One of the worst teachers I ever had! She was not able to teach without reading from her lectures, ironically enough for a communication teacher! I did not learn a thing during the whole semester. All we did was watching funny videos and looking up memes but her tests are actually super hard and have nothing to do with the lecture.

Professor Mapes is very fun and caring. The public speaking class was overall very easy. You will have to give numerous speeches, and will also need to speak and participate in class discussions as well. Attendance will affect your grade if you miss more than 4 classes. There are 2 exams in total, which you will need the textbook in order to pass.

Megan is very kind and ensures that the public speaking class is a comfortable space to give speeches. She gives lots of great feedback and does help you improve over the semester. I fully recommend taking her if you are taking a public speaking course.

I did not really like this class. Attendance is mandatory and sometimes she does random extra credit papers in class. There is a weekly reading with quizzes in Pearson that can be found on quizlet. For the tests there is a lockdown browser but no camera. I did not learn much but her class is easy to get an A in. There is one group project.
A very kind teacher, tough on grading but fair.
Super kind professor, a harsh grader but fair.

She had no clear control of her classroom and all we did was debate, despite the fact that it was a communications class. If you're extroverted and like talking, go for it. If you prefer to stay quiet, avoid her as much as possible.
Definitely make sure you show up to class! She doesn't really teach much so the workbook is really important to have.

You have to do 5 speeches in total. You do need a textbook and the workbook but purchase the workbook bc everything comes from it. The textbook you really don't need, you can find it online and also her midterm quizzes are online. The speeches can be easy if you prioritize work on them in advance. She honestly doesn't help much, she just grades.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Hilarious--Graded by few things

comment: Megan Mapes is an AMAZING professor who provides great feedback. She's also really cool too and actually cares about her students. She responds really quickly to emails too.
She genuinely cares about her students and only want you in class if you want to be there. The quizzes are very easy.

I took Professor Mapes for public speaking. Mapes' skill in the area is clear and she is more than willing to assist students in refining their public speaking skills. The class consists of five speeches, which are all doable. Mapes has a good relationship with her students and each class starts with a discussion that serves as an ice-breaker.
